original_text: ...the pacing is a bit slow and the story feels a bit predictable. I mean, David Cronenberg is known for his body horror and sci-fi themes, but this one just didn't quite live up to my expectations. The plot follows a woman who is going through a messy divorce and is also dealing with a mysterious illness that causes her to have psychic visions and physical transformations. It's a decent concept, but it feels like it's been done before and the execution is just a bit lacking. Additionally, the characters feel a bit one-dimensional and the acting is just okay. I mean, Oliver Reed is great as the villainous doctor, but the rest of the cast is just sort of...there. The special effects are also a bit dated, which takes away from the overall impact of the film. I mean, I know it's a 1979 film, but still, some of the makeup and prosthetics look pretty cheesy. Overall, while "The Brood" is still a decent film, it's not one of Cronenberg's best works. I mean, if you're a fan of his, you'll probably still enjoy it, but if you're new to his films, you might want to start with something like "Scanners" or "Videodrome" instead.
text: "The Brood" is a decent film, but it's not one of David Cronenberg's best works.Overall, I'm not a big fan of this film, so I'll probably be avoiding it for the next few weeks. Overall, while " The Brood's" still a respectable film, it'd be a good idea to avoid it if you're new to Cronenberg, because this one just doesn't live up to his reputation...well, let's just say it didn't quite live up...to my expectations... at least in terms of pacing and acting.

original_text: Jewish newspaper reporter Justin Timberlake (as Joshua "Josh" Pollack) is puzzled when a courtroom defendant whispers "Thank you" to testifying officer LL Cool J (as Rafe Deed) as he leaves the witness stand. In the opening sequences of this film, you are given the explanation. You will see Mr. Cool J's devilish detective partner Dylan McDermott (as Frances "Laz" Lazerov) decide NOT to murder Damien Dante Wayans (as Isaiah Charles). The cops in the city of "Edison" are so corrupt they shoot their suspects, steal their money, and snort their dope. Whether he's out to impress his girlfriend (herein, called "Pussy") or win a Pulitzer, the city's corruption does NOT sit well with the noble Mr. Timberlake.Timberlake decides to investigate the corruption, which reaches both unexpected scope and life-threatening levels of danger. Writer/director David J. Burke keeps the film above water, but just barely. LL Cool J beats Timberlake in the "pop star to movie star" sweepstakes (aka the "rapper to actor" progression). Mr. McDermott has fun with his role. Lending gravitas to the proceedings are sagely supporting actors Morgan Freeman (as Moses Ashford) and Kevin Spacey (as Levon Wallace). F.R.A.T. means First Response Assault and Tactical, but it's more important to know that "Edison (Force)" stars Justin Timberlake and LL Cool J, not Morgan Freeman and Kevin Spacey (who seems lost).**** Edison (9/17/05) David J.

original_text: ...it's a thought-provoking and visually stunning sci-fi film that explores themes of consumerism, conformity, and the dangers of unchecked corporate power. The movie's futuristic world, where Rollerball has become the ultimate form of entertainment and a way for the ruling elite to maintain control over the masses, is both fascinating and unsettling. The film's use of fast-paced action and high-stakes competition serves as a commentary on our own society's obsession with sports and entertainment, and how these distractions can be used to divert attention away from the issues that truly matter. James Caan's performance as Jonathan E, the rebellious Rollerball player, is also noteworthy for its intensity and nuance. Overall, "Rollerball" is a classic film that has aged surprisingly well, and its themes and warnings are just as relevant today as they were when the movie was first released in the 1970s.

original_text: Many mystery stories follow the standard whodunit path: murder most foul, gathering of clues, gaggle of possible perps, sprinkling of red herrings, and inevitable showdown between clever evildoer and even more clever crime solver."Forgotten" abandons the well-trod and gives us complex characters who may or may not have committed terrible acts. The fact that at the end of three episodes we have no easy answers and no neatly-tied package might frustrate some, but for me it was the indication of an intelligently crafted tale which probes, disturbs, and haunts with the question: What does an evil person look like?Excellent acting and production combine to make a mystery not easily.... forgotten.

original_text: ...the film's unique blend of fantasy and adventure was overshadowed by its meandering pace and underdeveloped characters. I mean, I loved the idea of a group of kids stumbling upon a map that leads them on a wild adventure through time and space, but the execution just didn't quite live up to my expectations. The special effects, while impressive for their time, looked a bit dated and cheesy to my modern eyes. And the characters, aside from Randall and Winston, felt a bit one-dimensional and lacked real depth or development. I just didn't feel like I was invested in their journey or cared about what happened to them. Plus, the film's tone was all over the place - it veered wildly from slapstick comedy to dark and ominous moments, and it never quite found a consistent balance. I think Terry Gilliam's direction was trying to be too clever and ambitious, and it ended up feeling like a mess. Overall, while "Time Bandits" had some interesting ideas and visuals, it just didn't hold up for me as a cohesive or engaging film. I think I was expecting something more from a Terry Gilliam movie, especially given his reputation for pushing the boundaries of storytelling and visual style.

original_text: I watched this movie with some curiosity. I wanted to see if 1) Paul Muni could play Chinese and 2) Luise Rainer deserved her Oscar. I came away from the film thinking YES! Having seen Muni in only one film where he was quite hammy, I expected the same type of performance here. I was happily proved wrong. Although some might criticize him as being too childlike and stereotypically simple in the Hollywood idea of Asians, I thought he was just right in the role. Keye Luke, if he'd been given the chance to play a lead role, might have played him in much the same manner.I was particularly impressed by the camera work and the use of crowd scenes, especially during the sacking of the palace where O-Lan was once a slave. The graphic and grim atmosphere of the firing squad and the drought made this an epic quite unlike others of the same time where it was all glitz and glitter. I watched this film from beginning to end enthralled. I can't say the same for the "epics" of today.
text: I watched this movie with some curiosity. I wanted to see if 1) Paul Muni could play Chinese and 2) Luise Rainer deserved her Oscar. I came away from the film thinking YES! Having seen Muni in only one film where he was quite hammy, I expected the same type of performance here. I was happily proved wrong. Although some might criticize him as being too childlike and stereotypically simple in the Hollywood idea of Asians, I thought he was just right in the role. Keye Luke, if he'd been given the chance to play a lead role, might have played him in much the same manner.I was particularly impressed by the camera work and the use of crowd scenes, especially during the sacking of the palace where O-Lan was once a slave. The graphic and grim atmosphere of the firing squad and the drought made this an epic quite unlike others of the same time where it was all glitz and glitter. I watched this film from beginning to end enthralled. I can't say the same for the "epics" of today.

original_text: "Clint Eastwood shines as Philo Beddoe, a truck driver with a pet orangutan, in this 1978 comedy. The film's mix of humor and action works surprisingly well, with Eastwood's deadpan delivery and the lovable ape, Clyde, stealing the show. A fun, lighthearted romp with plenty of laughs."
text: Clint Eastwood's latest film, The Good, the Bad and the Ugly, is rated PG by the Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA) for "plots, nudity, language, and some drug content" and "brief sensuality."
